title: 104_hr2278
content: The "Import Control and Safe Handling of Spent Nuclear Fuel Act of 1995" prohibits the import of spent nuclear fuel. The "Import Control and Safe Handling of Spent Nuclear Fuel Act of 1995" prohibits the import of spent nuclear fuel into the United States unless specific conditions are met. SEC. 3. NATIONAL SECURITY EXCEPTIONS. The prohibition on importing spent nuclear fuel does not apply to countries not authorized to possess nuclear weapons under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, but suspected of producing or developing nuclear weapons. The President must notify the relevant congressional committees at least 30 days prior. The President must notify congressional committees 30 days in advance of imported fuel arrival. Samples of spent nuclear fuel for national security testing are exempt from the prohibition. SEC. 4. GUIDELINES BY PORT AUTHORITIES TO ENSURE SAFE SHIPMENT OF CERTAIN MATERIAL. Port authorities can establish guidelines through a public comment process to ensure safe handling of spent nuclear fuel at ports. These guidelines must protect public health, safety, and the environment. Compliance with the guidelines is required for any unloading, transfer, or shipment of nuclear fuel. Guidelines may include various safety measures. Port authorities can establish guidelines for safe handling of spent nuclear fuel at ports. Guidelines may include worker training, a response plan for emergencies, and informing local communities about fuel activities. Compliance with these guidelines is necessary for any nuclear fuel activities at the port. Port authorities can establish guidelines for safe handling of spent nuclear fuel at ports, including informing local communities about fuel activities and possible consequences. Guidelines may also include standards for storage or parking of casks and transport vehicles carrying spent nuclear fuel. The guidelines at ports for handling spent nuclear fuel include restrictions on movement during certain conditions to minimize radiation exposure and accident risks. Worker radiation exposure levels must not exceed public standards set by regulation. Subsection (a) applies to guidelines that prioritize public health protection. The guidelines for handling spent nuclear fuel at ports prioritize public health protection and safety. Subsection (a) applies only to guidelines that are more protective than other applicable requirements under Federal, State, or local law. The existence of other laws governing the unloading, transfer, or shipment of spent nuclear fuel does not prevent the adoption or enforcement of guidelines under subsection (a). The Act prioritizes public health and safety in handling spent nuclear fuel at ports. It clarifies that the Act does not impact the liability or indemnification of ports in handling nuclear materials. Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act defines "atomic energy defense activity" as functions carried out by the Secretary of Energy, including naval reactors development, weapons activities, verification technology, nuclear materials production, waste management, and materials security. The Act defines "atomic energy defense activity" as functions carried out by the Secretary of Energy, including defense nuclear waste and materials management, security investigations, research and development. The term "port authority" refers to any authority overseeing port operations in the US, while "repository" is defined as per the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982. The Act defines "repository" and "spent nuclear fuel" according to the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982.
